messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for September 23, 2020 - September 29, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-09-30T18:55:10Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-09-23T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-09-29T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200930-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at minor levels during the reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 6 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=6 occurred during the synoptic period 2020-09-27T21:00Z to 2020-09-28T00:00Z. This moderate geomagnetic storm was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 on 2020-09-27. Solar wind speed reached values of about 650 km/s on 2020-09-28.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu starting at 2020-09-24T15:30Z and stayed elevated throughout the reporting period (see notifications 20200924-AL-001, 20200924-AL-002, 20200926-AL-001, 20200928-AL-003).  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated with the arrivals of two coronal hole high speed streams; the first of which arrived on 2020-09-24 and the second on 2020-09-27.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:

Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-09-30T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-10-06T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be at low to minor levels for the upcoming week. Active region 2773 should remain visible on the Earth-facing disk for most of the upcoming week with additional active regions appearing on the Earth-facing disk. Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low to minor levels as coronal hole structures become less geoeffective over the coming days. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt is expected to remain elevated over the next few days.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-09-30T12:56:45Z
## Message ID: 20200930-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated above 1000 pfu; the fluxes have sustained levels above 70% of this threshold since 2020-09-28T21:35Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2020-09-28T07:55Z are caused by a high speed stream which was measured at L1 on 2020-09-27. (See previous notification 20200928-AL-003.)

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2020-09-28T07:55:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-09-28T16:22:32Z
## Message ID: 20200928-AL-003
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2020-09-28T07:55Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2020-09-27T17:38Z, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 660 km/s. The solar wind speed at L1 is currently measured to be around 570 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2020-09-28T07:55:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 

This ongoing event is preceded by a radiation belt enhancement first observed at 2020-09-24T15:30Z which is associated with a high speed stream starting at 2020-09-24T02:50Z (see notifications 20200924-AL-001, 20200924-AL-002, and 20200926-AL-001).

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-09-28T12:43:27Z
## Message ID: 20200928-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2020-09-27T21:00Z to 2020-09-28T00:00Z. 

The storm is caused by a high speed stream starting at 2020-09-27T17:38Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2020-09-27T21:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-09-26T15:34:47Z
## Message ID: 20200926-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 1000 pfu starting at 2020-09-24T15:30Z (see notification ID 20200924-AL-002). The electron flux continues to be elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2020-09-26T13:10Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2020-09-24T02:50Z. The current solar wind speed is around 580 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2020-09-24T15:30:00-RBE-001. 


## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for September 16, 2020 - September 22, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-09-23T18:44:01Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-09-16T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-09-22T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200923-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.     

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:

Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-09-23T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-09-29T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels for the upcoming week. An unnumbered active region has rotated onto the Earth-facing disk as seen in the available imagery and had some minor activity in the last few days. Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels. There are several diffuse coronal hole structures visible on the Earth-facing disk that could become geoeffective as early as 2020-09-23. 

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for September 09, 2020 - September 15, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-09-16T19:28:09Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-09-09T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-09-15T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200916-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 3 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained above or close to the threshold level of 1000 pfu through 2020-09-13 (see notifications 20200909-AL-001, 20200911-AL-001, 20200913-AL-001). These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt were associated with a high speed stream which arrived around 2020-08-31.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.


##Events:

Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-09-16T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-09-22T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be at low to moderate levels for the upcoming week. All unnumbered active regions have begun to rotate off the Earth-facing disk as seen in the available imagery. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be between low and minor levels with the possibility of intermittent high speed streams resulting from diffuse, low-latitude coronal hole structures beginning as early as 2020-09-18.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-09-07T13:17:59Z
## Message ID: 20200907-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notifications with Activity ID 2020-09-01T10:20:00-RBE-001 (notifications 20200903-AL-001 and 20200905-AL-001).

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2020-09-01T10:20Z. The electron flux has continued to be elevated and has stayed above the threshold since the last crossing at 2020-09-06T06:05Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2020-08-31T06:52Z which reached a speed of 637 km/s. The current solar wind speed is around 360 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2020-09-01T10:20:00-RBE-001.

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earths outer radiation belt. GOES greater than 2.0 MeV integral electron flux remains elevated above 1000 pfu since 2020-08-30T10:55Z.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 26, 2020 - September 01, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-09-03T01:10:22Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-08-26T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-09-01T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200903-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period. No Earth-directed CMEs were measured during the reporting period.

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods 2020-08-28T15:00Z-18:00Z, 2020-08-31T03:00Z-06:00Z and 2020-08-31T:09Z-12:00Z. These minor geomagnetic storms were associated with the arrival of two coronal hole high speed streams detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 respectively around 2020-08-28 and 2020-08-31. Solar wind speed reached values of ~630 km/s on 2020-09-01.

An S-type CME which started at 2020-08-27T11:00Z as seen in SOHO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A was observed by STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments to arrive at STEREO-A around 2020-09-01T10:15Z, however the exact timing has been difficult to determine due to an 8-hour data gap preceding the possible arrival signature. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu starting at 2020-08-30T10:55Z and stayed elevated throughout the reporting period (see notifications 20200830-AL-002 and 20200901-AL-001). These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated with the aforementioned coronal hole high speed streams. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above and the CME arrival at STEREO-A towards the end of the reporting period.

None Observed

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-09-02T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-09-08T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be at low levels for the upcoming week. There is a large filament structure at mid-latitudes of the central disk which, if it erupts, might affect the Earth, but it has remained quiet since releasing an S-type CME on 2020-08-31T02:24Z directed at STEREO-A, with a possible glancing blow to STEREO-A predicted on 2020-09-04T08:00Z. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week. Currently, the solar wind speed detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 has values of ~480 km/s due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above; as the influence of the high speed stream subsides conditions will return to nominal values in the next few days.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-09-01T12:38:23Z
## Message ID: 20200901-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notification with Activity ID 2020-08-30T10:55:00-RBE-001 (see notification 20200830-AL-002).

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu, initially crossing this threshold at 2020-08-30T10:55Z. The electron flux has continued to be above this threshold, with the latest crossing at 2020-09-01T10:20Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2020-08-28T15:26Z, which has continued to increase in speed. The current solar wind speed is around 575 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2020-08-30T10:55:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:
